Do we really need to charge someone being tried for armed robbery or worse with an additional petty weapons charge?

Actually, in regards to possession by felons, they are not petty weapons charges-at least in Virginia. Say for example you catch a crack dealer with a gun. He could get anywhere from a minimum of 5 years up to 40 years for selling crack, but in my experience if he pleads guilty it would be a very, very rare occurrence for him to receive an active sentence of more than 2 years per charge for being a drug dealer. This is because the judge can suspend any part of or all of his sentence, and pursuant to this judicial authority the average sentence I see for per count of selling crack is 12-18 months. But if you catch him with a gun while he is selling, then the punishment for just on offense of having the gun is an automatic 5 years which cannot be suspended. I have seen many instances where the defendant gets far more time for having a gun than what he received for the actual underlying crime he commits either with or while having the gun.  But to come back to the issue, if registration is aimed at identifying and/or preventing illegal transfers and illegal possession of firearms, then in my opinion that goal cannot be reached because it cannot be enforced. Felons found in possession are already prosecuted for having the gun without a requirement to register them. A registration requirement will not aid in either their detection or prosecution because they will not comply with the registration requirement's command that they incriminate themselves-and no law can force them to register their guns so long as the 5th. Amendment remains a part of the Constitution.
